Dear Ms. Lessnau:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
October 24, 2018 and October 25, 2018. Due to the violations of applicable licensing
rules, sections of the contract and Implementation Sustainability Exit Plan (ISEP)
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the MSA and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and which
are less than 12 months old.
Two of twenty new employee records reviewed showed of three
references documented one or more references were not dated.
It could not be discerned if the reference was received prior to
the employee’s date of hire
Repeat Violation Renewal 2017.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this rule:
(g) If the employee has criminal convictions, the institution
shall complete a written evaluation of the convictions that
addresses the nature of the conviction, the length of time since
the conviction, and the relationship of the conviction to regulated
activity for the purpose of determining suitability for employment
in the institution.
(h) A statement from the employee regarding any convictions.
One of twenty new employee records reviewed showed a
criminal conviction. A staff person had written language such as,
approved and discussed with employee, on a file document, but
a written revaluation or statement as required by(g) and (h) was
not documented.
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2017,
1

R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of human
services, the equivalent state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the person usually
resides, that the person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. The documentation
shall be completed not more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months thereafter.
Four of twenty new employee records reviewed did not show
compliance:
Three records showed the clearance from the Department was
more than 30 days prior to the employee’s date of hire.
A fourth record showed the clearance from the Department was
one day after the employee’s date of hire.
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2017,
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and
shall include documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance within
30 days of the completion of the probationary period or within
180 days, whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
Seven of twenty-eight employee records reviewed did not show
compliance:
One employee’s record did not show documentation of a
probationary performance evaluation due by 8/23/18 for the
employee with a 2/23/18 date of hire.
A second, third, fourth and fifth employee’s records showed the
respective employee’s probationary performance evaluation
2

was late by, two, five, seventy-five and one hundred-fifth-three
days respectively.
A sixth employee’s record showed the employee was promoted
9/21/17, and the employee’s probationary performance
evaluation was completed late on 8/14/18.
A seventh employee’s record showed the employee was
promoted 4/20/18. A late 3/28/18 annual evaluation was
documented, but a probationary performance evaluation, due
10/20/18, for the new position was not documented.
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2017.
R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that each
employee and volunteer who has contact with residents 4 or
more hours per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free
from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable
tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current verification.
Three of twenty-eight employee records reviewed did not show
compliance:
One new employee record showed the employee’s tuberculosis
screening was completed one day after the employee’s 9/28/17
date of hire.
A second and third employee’s record showed the employee’s
annual tuberculosis screening completed 2/7/18, and 6/14/18,
was after the respective employee’s 1/24/18, and 5/17/18
tuberculosis screening’s due date.
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
The facility requires that staff administering medication initial the
MARS (Medication Administration Record) to show
documentation that the child was dispensed his or her
medication. A review of the facility’s medication logs showed
3

fifteen MARS which did not show a staff’s initial for one or more
medication administrations, for the respective child, in October
2018. A notation of refusal, or other reason why the medication
was not dispensed was not documented. Many of the missed
initials were for 10/19/18 morning and or evening.
R 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan.
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and date an
updated treatment plan for each resident at least once every 90-
calendar days following the updated treatment plan.
One of seven updated treatment plans was one day late.
Another was not dated by the supervisor.
R 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan.
(5) The social service supervisor shall approve, countersign,
and date the updated treatment plan.
One of seven updated treatment plans showed the clinical
director completed the treatment plan as the worker; and the
treatment plan did not contain a supervisor’s signature.
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.

Nothing this inspection.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The first incident related to Special Investigation 2018C0420022, initiated 12/28/17
pertaining to an allegation that a staff pushed a resident after he disrespected her.
The investigation found the staff had not tried to deescalate the child and had pushed
him. The agency received a violation under R400.4158(2) for Discipline. The agency
submitted an acceptable corrective plan on 2/21/18. The staff was disciplined and
retrained in Crisis Prevention Intervention (CPI). The agency was not successful with
this corrective action plan. It received a repeat violation related to the same staff in
Special Investigation 2018C0420051.
The second incident related to Special Investigation 2018C0420051, initiated 8/23/18
pertaining to an allegation a staff shoveled a child after she intervened to take a fork
from him and he tried to kick her. The investigation found the agency in violation of
R400.4158(2) for Discipline. The agency submitted an acceptance corrective plan on
10/23/18 that indicated the employee received a two-day suspension. The staff was
also alerted that another infraction of this rule/the agency’s behavior management
policy will result in termination. All staff were reminded to utilize the proper CPI
technique, which emphasis de-escalation.
The facility has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
This corrective action plan related to the agency’s Renewal Inspection where it
received eleven rule type citations and three contract violations. It submitted an
acceptable corrective action plan; but was not totally successful with that corrective
action plan. It received five repeat violations this inspection, as documented in the
body of this report. These violations related to employee records and updated
service plans. Not withstanding that, the agency’s number of citations decreased this
6

inspection. It is also worth noting the agency underwent another staffing change this
inspection. It has a new chief administrator, residential services director, various
other departmental staff changes were also noted, inclusive of the loss or termination
of many prior youth specialists. The agency is trying to maintain a resident census of
not more than twenty-five to provide persistent and specialized intervention with its
residents. Additionally, the agency has restructured it employee’s filing system,
revised various policies, and retrained all staff in its Crisis Prevention Intervention
behavior management methodology. The agency appears to be adjusting to the staff,
administration, and programmatic changes.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on their regular license.
